Award.AwardTitle: Reduction of Financial Barriers By Providing Academic Scholarships in the Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Through this scholarship program, Saint Augustine's University (SAU) attracts, supports and retains in interrelated majors with an emphasis in Science, Technology, Engineering & Mathematics (STEM) to increase the the quantity and quality of STEM graduates. SAU serves a geographic niche in North Carolina which is characterized by higher proportion of minority residents in a rural setting that are often afflicted by persistent poverty. The program goals are: 1) to achieve full retention of talented but financially disadvantaged undergraduates majoring in the sciences, while significantly reducing their time to graduation; and 2) increase the number of underrepresented minorities, who elect and are well-prepared to pursue advanced degrees in the sciences and pursue educational, leadership and managerial roles in STEM fields. This project supports a STEM initiative that increases and strengthens partnerships, networks and collaborations between this HBCU and mainstream universities, state and regional forensic and health sciences laboratories, USDA and other STEM research-related enterprises. The project targets 30 full-time SAU students majoring in one of the following STEM disciplines; Biology, Chemistry, Forensic Science, Engineering Mathematics, Mathematics, and Computer Science. Each scholarship recipient will have a designated Faculty Mentor to guide academic and research development. The recipients each are assigned a Faculty Mentor and participate in academic development activities and work as peer tutors to promote experiences and progress in cohort groups. A rich array of opportunities are available to the scholarship recipients including the Science Seminar Series, tutoring sessions, summer internship opportunities at on-campus and off-campus laboratories, service learning activities, field trips, faculty-student collaborative research, attendance at conferences, alumni mentoring, and comprehensive career counseling. Programmatic evaluation will focus on multiple factors, including improved student learning, problem solving abilities, performance on exams, teamwork, presentation skills, graduation rates, job placement in field of study, and pursuit of higher education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the Saint Augustine?s University NSF S-STEM Initiative Trainee Program was implemented to provide financial support to highly talented, enthusiastic and motivated students from under-represented minority groups who might not otherwise have the resources to complete the degree requirements of a STEM major.  These scholarships provided additional financial stability that allowed students to focus primarily on the rigorous coursework and extracurricular activities required to obtain the degree in a timely manner. The overall goal of the proposed project was to increase the number of Saint Augustine?s University science majors that graduate and are prepared for, apply to, are accepted, matriculate and succeed in graduate studies leading to graduate degrees and employment in a broad range of STEM disciplines.

 In addition to scholarships, program activities helped to improve student preparation and success in securing immediate placement and matriculation into graduate/professional schools and/or the STEM workforce. These activities included a tutorial service for S-STEM Scholars enrolled in freshmen introductory biology, chemistry and mathematics courses.  The Science Seminar Series graduate/professional school recruiters provided information about graduate and professional school opportunities. Other recruiters provided information about opportunities and requirement careers in STEM disciplines. The S-STEM Scholars were included in a group email list that receives information about summer research internships, graduate or professional school announcements (including funding), and job listings from potential STEM employers.

To improve retention, S-STEM Scholars participated in the School of Sciences Peer Mentoring Program. The goal of the SSME Peer Mentoring Experience Program is to assist 1st year, 2nd year, and transfer students transition into college and develop their sense of self identity. It also helps to enhance their ability to integrate and engage productively with their peers and faculty, and to develop academic and soft skills necessary for successful completion of requirements in their STEM major. STEM courses are assessed and revised on an ongoing basis to meet the needs of students and to better prepare them for graduate school and the STEM workforce. In particular, the two capstone courses, BIOL 401/MATH 495 ? Introduction to Research and BIOL 420/MATH 496 are constantly assessed and revised as necessary. S-STEM Scholars provided valuable feedback that helped revise STEM curricula.

 

Research shows that participation in undergraduate research plays a major role in student success in STEM disciplines. In that regard, 55 of the 62 S-STEM Scholars participated in at least one Summer Research Internship. We believe that this was an integral part of student preparation for graduate school and made them more competitive in the STEM workforce. Many of these opportunities were supported by NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) supplements secured by Principal Investigators at their respective summer research sites. In addition, eight S-STEM scholars conducted their senior research projects in The Laboratory of Genetics and Integrative Research during the academic year (established in part due to an NSF RIA grant secured by the PI) on campus. All S-STEM Scholars attended and presented their research at one or more STEM-related local, regional and/or national conference.

 

A major outcome of the NSF S-STEM Initiative Trainee Program was an increase in student graduation with a degree in biology, chemistry or engineering mathematics. During the 5-year program 62 S-STEM Scholars participated. To date, 49 S-STEM Scholars graduated with a STEM degree and eight are currently enrolled and are on schedule to graduate in May 2021. To date, of the 49 S-STEM graduates, 27 have matriculated into graduate or professional school in STEM. Three scholars were commissioned into the US Army as 2nd Lieutenants. Most of the others found employment within a year in a STEM-related employer.
